image.altText: Tait thunderbolt finds its target

props.synopsis: Shaun Tait's 161.1 kilometres per hour delivery in 2010 was the fastest ball ever bowled by an Australian and the second fastest ever bowled. Experts are concerned coaching methods may be hindering others from reaching those levels again.

title.children: Fast bowling records will stay unless coaches 'let them be aggressive'

image.altText: GettyImages-2210471485

props.synopsis: The Sydney Swans fall short after launching a spirited fightback against Port Adelaide, while the Western Bulldogs prepare to face St Kilda in Marcus Bontempelli's return appearance. Follow live.

title.children: Bulldogs regain superstar Bontempelli for blockbuster Easter clash with Saints

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Swans respond to Aliir Aliir incident
Ollie Wines subbed off with heart issue

image.altText: A drone shot of a crash at a highway intersection. Grey smoke is billowing from the two trucks surrounded by police cars

props.synopsis: A South Australian truck driver has been charged with causing death by dangerous driving after a fatal truck crash. Police are urging any witnesses to speak with investigators.

title.children: Truck driver arrested after fatal crash on South Australian highway

image.altText: A tiny baby short-necked turtle held up by someone in their hand near a lake.

props.synopsis: Native freshwater turtles have declined by up to 91 per cent in parts of the River Murray, but Indigenous rangers and conservationists are fighting to bring them back.

title.children: First Nations rangers fight to save 'vacuum cleaners of the river'

image.altText: Ladybirds gathered on dry grass with others behind on the ground

props.synopsis: Dry but cool conditions in South Australia's south east are causing ladybirds to gather in huge numbers, which an ecologist says will help control a destructive plant pest.

title.children: Millions of ladybirds descend on SA town to eat pine tree pest

image.altText: Statue holding the scales of justice (Reuters)

props.synopsis: The controversial law of sacrilege — which carries the same maximum penalty of life in jail as murder — still exists in South Australia, but some say it shouldn't.

title.children: An SA man faces life in prison for sacrilege. What does the controversial charge mean?

image.altText: Five boys play kabaddi wearing red shorts and no shirt on a sports oval.

props.synopsis: Junior players of a traditional Indian sport are allowed to compete at the Australian Sikh Games for the first time in the event's 37-year history.

title.children: Youngsters to compete in ancient sport for first time at Sikh games

image.altText: A man with a blue apron stands in a room full of packaged chocolate

props.synopsis: Small businesses working over the busy Easter period are counting the cost of rising prices, global economic uncertainty and customers who are becoming more frugal.

title.children: Small businesses feel the pinch amid busy Easter period

image.altText: Sebastian Johnston is grinning

props.synopsis: After waking from a week-long induced coma, Sebastian Johnston was diagnosed with epilepsy and an acquired brain injury. Now he is calling for more understanding for young people living with the condition.

title.children: People living with epilepsy can 'slip through the cracks', advocates say

image.altText: Two firefighters stand on a creek bed with a fire hose jetting into the creek. They are surrounded by blackened trees and grass,

props.synopsis: South Australians are being urged to take care with campfires over Easter, as the fire danger season is extended for the Mount Lofty Ranges. Beachgoers are also being warned to assess local conditions as an algal bloom persists along parts of the coast.

title.children: Easter travellers warned of fire danger, algal bloom

image.altText: A farmer stands on a piece of rusted machinery in the middle of a farm

props.synopsis: Despite applying for government drought funding months ago, one South Australian farmer says he is still waiting for assistance.

title.children: Farmer waits on drought relief payments for months

image.altText: black and white photo of a woman with dark hair in a pale shirt, vest and beads with elbow on table resting head on knuckles

props.synopsis: In 1972 an Australian woman could not even open a bank account without the backing of a man. This is the inside story of how a group of feminists forced political change.

title.children: Meet the woman who turned female votes into political dynamite

image.altText: Matthew Draganoff in front of a Union Jack flag

props.synopsis: Matthew Draganoff is standing trial accused of the shooting murder of his tenant, Simon Middleton. Prosecutors allege there had been an "accumulation of grievances" that led to the crime.

title.children: Man allegedly murdered tenant over 'growing animosity', jury told

image.altText: A QantasLink plane on the tarmac

props.synopsis: Passengers out of SA's biggest regional city could soon see a spike in flight prices as more airports are forced to bring in security screening.

title.children: Mount Gambier airport passengers face 'unsustainable' $90 fare hike

image.altText: Stella  hugs her daughter as they walk along the footpath outside the District Court

props.synopsis: A woman who was abused at the hands of her ex-partner – a former police detective – says she felt "silenced" after reaching out to SA Police, a court has heard. Their daughter also recounted his abuse and said she no longer considered him her father.

title.children: 'I will not be silenced': Woman confronts abusive ex-cop husband in court

image.altText: An Indigenous man wearing a cap, watch and black singlet looks up at a camera while seated outdoors.

props.synopsis: Brenton Shar walked away from his father's house one dark night and never came home. His family is still searching for answers, as a senator calls for a federal investigation into missing Indigenous men in Australia.

title.children: On a dark night, Brenton left his dad's home and was never seen again

image.altText: An Indigenous man wearing a cap and black singlet stares at the camera while someone puts an arm on his shoulder.

props.synopsis: Brenton Shar walked away from his father's house one dark night and never came home. His family is still searching for answers, as a senator calls for a federal investigation into missing Indigenous men in Australia.

title.children: A mysterious phone call and pair of shorts a family's only clues in missing man search

image.altText: Police officers stand on the footpath of a city street which is blocked by police tape at night.

props.synopsis: Homicide Squad detectives are investigating the death of a man in Melbourne's inner south-east this morning, along with an unrelated serious assault of a woman in the coastal town of Barwon Heads.

title.children: Man fatally stabbed in Melbourne's popular Chapel Street nightclub strip

image.altText: A man in a white space suit in carried by others in blue

props.synopsis: NASA astronaut Don Pettit, who spent 220 days in the ISS and orbited the Earth 3,520 times, landed back on Earth in Kazakhstan on Saturday local time.

title.children: NASA astronaut celebrates 70th birthday with return to Earth

image.altText: Peter Dutton inspecting new housing development.

props.synopsis: Coalition MPs say 14 days is an eternity in politics and the party can reclaim ground before voting day in two weeks' time — even as it fends off new claims the Coalition would revive its unpopular work from home plan after the election.

title.children: Coalition frontbenchers say party not 'waving a white flag'

image.altText: A woman shopping for groceries.

props.synopsis: Vote Compass data shows cost of living is the most important issue for respondents ahead of the federal election.

title.children: Vote Compass data shows rise in importance of cost of living for voters

image.altText: A man smiles widely as he stands in front of a large wooden cross on a grassy hill with the sun rising in the background

props.synopsis: The faithful have gathered throughout Australia to mark one of the holiest days on the Christian calendar.

title.children: Australian Christians celebrate Easter Sunday across the nation

image.altText: A portrait photo of a man in a suit with glasses with an interior of an office in the background

props.synopsis: Two student reporters scramble to cover Harvard’s funding freeze amid escalating tensions with Donald Trump.

title.children: Harvard will not 'kiss the ring' as its law professors sue the US government

image.altText: A young girl with her brown hair in a pony tail in a pink jumper holds her hands under her chin as she gazes at a keyboard.

props.synopsis: Parents and researchers hope the discovery of a genetic mutation could help find treatments for children living with previously undiagnosed neurodevelopmental disorders.

title.children: Discovery of genetic mutation leads to first diagnosis for dozens of kids

image.altText: Woman wearing intricate gold costume and black makeup on face.

props.synopsis: If Donald Trump can be president, Deborah Kelly reasoned, then she could start a religion. The artist's project began as a parody, but soon morphed into a genuine source of spiritual solace for a growing community.

title.children: This religion started as a 'joke', then it took on a life of its own

image.altText: Clive Palmer National Press Club

props.synopsis: Dominant parties imply the choice is a narrow binary but in reality Australian contests are increasingly determined by third party campaigns.

title.children: The question this election is whether the centre can hold

image.altText: A man in black is at the bottom centre of the image with two flags looming behind him

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says Russian artillery fire has not subsided despite the Kremlin announcing an Easter ceasefire.

title.children: Zelenskyy says Russian attacks continuing despite 'Easter truce'

image.altText: A young man gestures while speaking and sitting on the couch

props.synopsis: Dissatisfaction with the Albanese government's stance on Israel-Palestine among many Arab and Muslim voters threatens to unseat Labor MPs, in some places for the first time.

title.children: 'Enormously betrayed': Gaza pain mobilises Australian Muslim voters

image.altText: Woman looking at paper document

props.synopsis: An antithesis to mass-produced chipboard furniture, a Tasmanian designer is making pieces that should last "hundreds of years".

title.children: You've heard of fast fashion. What about fast furniture?

image.altText: A woman dressed up as a grandmother, standing on an apple float in a parade.

props.synopsis: The Granny Smith green apple is one of Australia's most famous exports — and it's all thanks to the propagating prowess of a grandmother.

title.children: A 'chance seedling' in a Sydney backyard became a fruit staple for the world

image.altText: A man in a red polo sits on top of a bus in front of a red hill, with workers listening to him.

props.synopsis: As a storm brews over federal industrial relations changes, government critics say increased worker power will take the resource-rich Pilbara region back to the "bad old days" of union power. But how bad were they?

title.children: Will the government's new IR laws bring the Pilbara back to the 'bad old days'?

image.altText: A crowd of people gathered with some waving banners and flags while Big Ben looms behind them in the background

props.synopsis: Trans rights protesters gather in the English capital to protest against the UK's Supreme Court ruling that a woman is someone born biologically female.

title.children: Thousands of trans rights supporters rally in Central London

image.altText: Luke Tribe and his new dog Fosse

props.synopsis: Luke Tribe didn't feel ready to get another dog soon after saying goodbye to his best friend of 10 years. But that time did eventually come.

title.children: When is the right time to get a dog after losing one?

image.altText: John Cruckshank on stage with mic in hand, hold other hand to his head

props.synopsis: The Sydney Comedy Festival celebrates its 20th anniversary with a program including some of Australia's best known comedians, new talent and guests from across the world.

title.children: A sparky, a therapist and a rich kid walk into the Sydney Comedy Festival…

image.altText: Bluey characters in puppet form with their puppeteers

props.synopsis: Experts weigh in on whether it's OK for parents to have downtime on their phones instead of playing with their children.

title.children: The Bluey episode that raises questions about parents' phone use
